> >--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Colin Green <cgreen@d...> wrote:
> But some junk may be a precursor to building some larger useful structure.

Well, I guess this is really an open question.  It's possible that
either neutral, or even maladaptive, structure could be coopted at a
later point and made useful.  Ken says he's seen jumps out of stagnant
stretches and seems to attribute it to this dynamic.  I guess I
haven't worked with NEAT enough to experience this phenomenon, but
there certainly could be other explanations.  For example, speciation
could be key in kicking out of stagnant stretches.

There was a discussion here not long ago about not allowing species
whose fitness hasn't increased in some time to reproduce.  It was
noted that this was an important dynamic.  Those jumps out of fitness
plateaus could be a result of the extinction of an old stagnant
species, making way for more innovation, and the introduction of a new
species.  I don't know...but it would be interesting to analyze the
population dynamics around such jumps and try to figure out what's
really going on.  This is just one possible explanation.  But without
some data to back it up, I'm somewhat skeptical about attributing
jumps out of local minima to the coadaptation of excess topology.

But if this proved to be the case, this seems counter to the
methodology of incrementally adding features and testing them along
the way.  If we have good reason to think that excess raw material
that's not adaptive now will become so at some point, and that this is
important to kicking out of stagnation, then why start minimally?

Why not start with a fair amount of junk?

On Sat, 29 May 2004 20:42:29 -0000, Kenneth Stanley
<kstanley@...> wrote:
> To the extent
> that your "bloated" solution works, you probably couldn't have
> gotten it to work in that larger space if you'd started in it
> directly, but now here you are in a more promising part of that
> space.  

But how do you know you're in a more promising part of the search
space?  It could be that all that excess neutral topology could become
adaptive at some point, but there's a greater likelihood that it will
not.

>  It even brings up a
> question which Derek, Philip, and I have talked about in email,
> which is whether the nice results for blended runs also apply in
> very complex domains.

Well, this may depend on the gradient of the fitness function.  I
think Shimon's notion of task decomposition addresses this. 
Basically, you wouldn't want to try to evolve a robotic soccer team
against a high-performing hand-coded team, based just on
wins/losses/ties.  Your evolving controllers will just lose every
time.  But if you can successfully decompose the problem (which real
soccer players do), into distinct objectives (dribbling, passing,
shooting) you can incrementally build up skills and hopefully combine
them to solve holistic goals, such as winning a game.

It seems to me that an incremental approach to improving fitness
correlates with the notion of incrementally adding topological
features and testing them along the way.

The other extreme might be to allow all sorts of non-adaptive topology
to pile up, and hope that it can be coopted for very complex
behaviors, like winning a soccer game.  So I don't think it's
necessarily the complexity of the domain, but the approach to fitness
along the way.

Derek
